title: Publications and Presentations
text:
Oral Presentations:

Where do we start looking?Analysis of Spatial Imaging Data . Presented virtually in the Biocompare Webinar Series “Overcoming Technical Challenges in Spatial Biology” on 21st November, 2024.
Methods for the characterization of tumor heterogeneity with a spatial context. Presented at the 6th Annual Symposium-Cancer Research: Basic Science to Bioinformatics at College Station, TX, on 29th September, 2023.
Analysis platforms to quantify tumor-immune interactions through multiplexed spatial profiling technologies. Presented at the 20th Discovery on Target(DOT) Conference at Boston, MA, on 25th September, 2023.
Location matters : Methods for the characterization of the tumor microenvironment with a spatial context. Presented at the 32nd Great Lakes International Imaging and Flow Cytometry Association at Madison, WI, on 9th-10th September, 2023.

title: Santhoshi N Krishnan
text:
I am currently a Postdoctoral Research Fellow in the department of Computational Medicine and Bioinformatics at the University of Michigan. My research entails developing statistical and machine learning-based models for the characterization of the disease microenvironment, with a special focus on the tumor-immune microenvironment(TIME).
My long-terms goals are to work on problems that have a positive real-world impact, with a focus of tackling problems in the healthcare domain. I am also passionate about understanding the impact of developed CDSS on the overall clinical workflow, and aim to develop frameworks that address the “needs” rather than the “wants” in the healthcare domain.

title: Updates and Ponderings
text:
Our Spatial Review is Out!
Very excited to have our monumental review on Spatial Omics out! Thank you Julienne Carstens and Jared K. Burks for inviting me to be a part of this monumental undertaking- especially Julie for seeing this through to the end! And thank you to the rest of the co-authors for their contributions as well. I contributed heavily on the downstream analysis and results section of the paper, including (what I believe to be) a very useful table on what spatial analysis methods one needs to pick based on their computational limitations and biological question under consideration.
Link to the paper here.
